Award.AwardTitle: Microscopic and Macroscopic Dynamics of Interacting Particle Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many interesting problems in science and engineering involve systems with large numbers of interacting constituents. Typical examples are gases and fluids, which are made out of many atoms, as well as granular media like sand. An important question for such systems is how to describe their behavior at large scales. For example, under what conditions is the collective dynamics of a large number of grains of sand similar to the behavior of a fluid, and when is it not? Questions like this are of considerable interest from a purely scientific point of view as well as for industrial applications ranging from coal processing to pharmaceutical and grain/food preparation lines. The objective of this research project is to advance the mathematical understanding of how microscopic dynamics gives rise to macroscopic behavior. Necessarily this requires study of specialized models. In this project several such models suitable for rigorous mathematical analysis are under study.

Very popular mechanical models in the mathematical studies of classical statistical mechanics are collisions between scatters, in particular dispersing billiards. Recent advances have shown that such systems have very strong statistical properties. However, these results are limited to a very small number of degrees of freedom. The PI proposes to rigorously investigate statistical properties of specific models having many degrees of freedom. Since the rigorous analysis of purely mechanical models with many degrees of freedom is mathematically very challenging, many models in statistical physics introduce additional random elements. This project will also mathematically study the hydrodynamic limit of a special class of randomly interacting particle systems, which are in fact very closely related to the models under study. For this purpose the PI will extend the techniques that were recently developed to analyze of the hydrodynamic limit of the dissipative Boltzmann equation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many interesting problems in science and engineering involve systems with many interacting constituents. Typical examples are gases and fluids, which are made out of many atoms, and granular media like sand. An important question for such systems is how to describe their behavior at larges scales. For example, under what conditions is the collective dynamics of a large number of grains similar to the behavior of a fluid, and when is it not. Questions like this are of considerable interest from a purely scientific point of view as well as for industrial applications.

Popular mechanical models in the mathematical studies of interacting particle systems are hard-sphere systems with or without random forcing. One of the central results of the work carried out with the help of this NSF award is the construction of a particular mechanical model of interacting hard-spheres which is argued to be a good candidate for future rigorous investigations of heat transport. A second central result we obtained is the extension of averaging theory to fully coupled slow-fast systems with singularities. In particular, we were able to give a mathematical foundation to a transport phenomenon related to cooling in a basic model of granular media.

Furthermore, we developed efficient numerical methods to simulate interacting particles systems of various kinds. In particular, we perform molecular dynamics simulations and numerical solutions of semi-Markov models described by stochastic differential equations with jumps. The numerical findings obtained by these methods motivated a rigorous analysis of semi-Markov processes and hydrodynamic systems with external driving. In particular, these works led to two successful PhD thesis of two of my PhD students.

The results obtained with the help of this award were published in high-quality peer-reviewed research journal papers. In addition, some of the findings are published as freely accessible electronic publications on the arxiv.org preprint server. The PI presented these works also in a large number of talks at national and international conferences, and seminars at various universities.

In addition, this research work not only successfully provided PhD thesis work for two PhD students, but it also provided continuous resources for our weekly dynamical systems working seminar. This seminar is our primary training platform for our PhD students and postdoctoral researchers with interest in dynamical systems and related topics (primarily stochastic processes), and a vital component in my teaching efforts. Other activities that this NSF award made possible include a number of talks to a primarily graduate student audience, and a number of trips to regional conference with some of our local graduate students.
